THE EASTERN TELEGRAPH
NORDEUTSCHER LLOYD
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.
The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindlei Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

RED SEA LINE.
Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

The Past Year
It is ever the tendency of journalism to exaggerate and to attach an absurd importance to the ephemeral matters which come within its province. The overweening attribute of "speech-making" is applied to merely sensa- tional events, for the horizon of the comment- ator on daily occurrences must necessarily be limited in a great measure by having no stable basis for dealing with the patches of complicat- ed events which are brought day to day within hi ken, and the continuity of the world's development is obscured behind a mass of scare headlines. When therefore we have to review the salient points of the past year, it is very difficult to avoid unduly dwelling on what merely appears to loom large not because it is important but because it is recent, and through an excessive desire for picturesqueness, or sen- sationalism, as many would prefer to term it, to present a purely external view of the course of affairs. But we do not think there will be many among our readerswho will venture to deride us if we hazard the statement that the year, which ends to-morrow, will ever be reck- oned as one of the cardinal dates in modern history, and that 1905 will hold a permanent niche in Universal History as the starting point of events which will exert an incalculably important influence on the destinies of man- kind, for in the sequence of those world-histor- ical occurrences which link all nations together, and control their destinies, the historian of the future will assuredly give a place to that deci- sive naval battle which gave Japan a foremost position among the great Powers of the world, and will ever reckon 1905, which saw the beginnings of the Russian revolution, as im- portant a date as the year which saw the meet- ings of the States-General and the storming of the Bastille. All the other events of the year sink into utter insignificance before such colossal facts, whence the beginnings of new eras in the history both of Europe and of Asia will be dated.
It is true that the revolution may even at this hour be checked, but its advance will only be stayed temporarily. It must be remembered that there is probably no people which has such a strong historic consciousness as the Russians. There has been no great break in their deve- lopment, no new object of their common effort. They have not undergone the transformation from an agricultural to an industrial civiliza- tion, which puts much into the background, and fills men's minds with new problems. There has been to them no sudden extension of boundaries. In their vast plains they always knew the world was large, and that numbers of their brethren might be added to their family - brethren already like-minded with themselves. Their past history is a long record of struggles after union, which might make them strong against barbarous invaders, of untold sufferings endured with patient perse- verance, of monotonous surrounding and con- stant conflict with churlish nature, In all this there are but two things that helped them- their Church, which bound them together and gave them courage to endure; their national leaders, who trained them into strength, drove back their foes, and welded them into a mighty nation. Indeed, there were not two but one, for Church and State are indissolubly connect- ed. There was no ecclesiastical system with an independent head whose claims might divide their allegiance. They received their Christia- ity from Byzantium, not from Rome. Their ruler inherits the claims of no Holy Roman Emperor crowned by a Pope, but is the repre- sentative of the rulers born in the purple chamber of the Bosphorus, and has never has to divide his authority with a bishop whose sway extended beyond his realm.
When this perople, so strong in their historic consciousness, determine to break with their past, we may be sure that the emancipation of the Slavs will be thorough. But the emancipa- tion of Japan from Europe may even be more far-reaching in its results than the Russian revo- lution, and the sudden apparition of an Asiatic state continuously triumphant over a European adversary is enough to give the boldest pause. It is for the men of this generation, nay, of the last two centuries, and unexampled pheno- menon. Not for more than a hundred years has any single Asiatic state taken the ini- tiative of making an attaach upon a European foe and achieved any success thereby. An unbroken series of campaigns waged by Europeans against Asiatics has led to the establishment of the fixed idea in the Euro- pean mind that Asia was the natural heritage of Europe, that the Asiatic was the natural prey of the European, and that whenever Asiatic and European met in battle, the Euro- pean inevitably and always came off victor, although the odds agasint him were ten or twenty to one. Numbers did not count in such contests. So it came to pass that, secure in the memory of innumerable victories in each of which this convenient working hypo- thesis was put to the test and verified by experiement of blood and fire, the European no more conceived of the possibility of a success- ful Asiatic revolt against his domination than the cowboys on the ranches conceive of the possibility of a revolt of the herds which they rule from the saddles of thie broncos. Now and then the European, like the cowboy, may get jammed in an ugly rush or unexpected stampede of his dumb-driven cattle. But it is only doe the moment, Europle always asserts herself and exacts terrible vengeance for her temporary discomfiture. So invariably has this been the rule that at this moment 70,000 armed white men suffice to garrison the whole of Asia south of the Himalayas from the Khyber in the west to the forest frontier of Burmo-China, a vast and caried region inhab- ited by more than 300,000,000 of human beings. That gives over 4,000 Asiatics to each white soldier. Cattle on the Western ranches require a greater proportion of cowboys per 1,000 head. It is not necessary to conjure up dread imaginations as to another invasion of Europe. It is enough to realise that Asia is at present parcelled out among European Powers who exist solely bythe prestige of a success achieved by use of European weapons and by the despair engendered in the hearts of Asiatics by their long-continued defeat. The victories of Japan will change all this. Even if Japan does not Japanise China, she will establish her position as paramount sea power in those Eastern waters. Suppose that she confines herself to the sea, it is obvious even to the meanest understanding that the whole political situation in Eastern waters, including Australia, will be revolutionised if she can maintain her present ascendancy. All islands will be held at her mercy- the Philippines, the Netherlands' East Indies, New Zealand, and Australia. The Japanese are 40,000,000 strong. Like the brave men of Marseilles, they know how to die. The story of their suicidal valous recalls the me- mories of the early days of Islam, and it is only rendered the more remarkable by the fact that their readiness to sacrifice their life does not appear to be sustained by any faith in the next. They have shown themselves to be quick to seize the advantaged offered by the weapons and the craft of the West. They have not studied in vain in the head- quarters staff of Germany or in the schools of the British navy. They are like other human beings, subject to the temptation of vanity, and they are not immune against the promptinfs of ambition. In the watchword, "Asia for the Asiatics," they have a weapon which may be used in a hundred centres at once, and which has already toused echoes beyond the Himalayas.
LOCAL AND GENERAL
Frost at Abbassieh. Frost was recorded at Abbassieh yesterday morning, the temperature being 2 Centigrade.
Diphtheria. An outbreak of diphtheria has occurred at Zeitoun and the schools have been closed.
The Charlotte. The German corvette Charlotte is leaving Alexandria for Italy at 2 o’clock this afternoon.
Tho Mahmal. Ahmed Effendi Aref, of Mansourah, has been appointed pharmacist to the medical staff accompanying the Mahmal to Mecca.
New Years Gifts. The establishment of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi in Old Bourse-street, Alexandria, will be opened throughout to-morrow (Sunday) for the convenience of the public.
Buried Alive. A native workman of 30 years was digging yesterday in a pit in Menascestreet, when he was buried under a heavy mass of earth, which fell upon him and asphyxiated him. His body was afterwards extricated.
All Saints, Cairo. By a notice in our advertising columns we see that there will be midnight service and celebration of Holy Communion at All Saints' Church, Cairo, on Sunday next, beginning at 11.15 p.m.
Coal Imports. From the 1st of January to the 28th inst. 1,042,768 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sent 572,414, Newcastle 227,879, Scotland 119,294, Yorkshire 78,636, and other places 44,560 tons. During the same period last year 1,050,482 tons were received.
Military Tournament. A meeting under the presidency of Lieut. Col. Markham, 1st Batt. Kings’ Royal Rifle Corps, will be held at Headquarters, Cairo, at 1.30 a.m. on Monday next, to consider arrangements for the forthcoming Military Tournament.
Concert at Parish-Room, Bulkeley. A most successful and much appreciated con- cert was held last night in the Parish Room, Bulkeley. A large and representative audience listened with evident delight to the songs, the charming composition, "The Daisy Chain," and the instrumental music, which, for an amateur performance, was of a first class order. A full account of this concert will appear in our next issue.
The New Organ for St. George's. Mr. John Davies, who erected the new organ for H.B.M.’s Garrison Church of St George, Mustapha Pasha, is deserving of the highest praise tor the able way in which he has put up the instrument. He is remaining a few days in Alexandria, and will be glad to give any information about the organs of the Posi- tive Organ Company, who make small organs, suitable for the drawing-room, as well as large ones for cathedrals and churches. Mr. Davies is going next week to Cairo, where his address will be at the Hotel du Nil.
Merchant Seamen's Home. The 'Xmas Treat given to the seamen in port at the Merchant Seaman's Home yesterday was a most brilliant affair from every point of view, and 300 men sat down to dinner in two relays. Pressure of space compels us to hold over our account of the entertainment. Lady Blomfield begs to acknowledge the following subscriptions and presents for the feast: Mr. Abdy, 10s. ; Mrs. Macaulay, £2 ; Mr. Chitty, £1; Mr. Ambrose Ralli, £1; Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, £1; Mrs. Dickson £1; Mrs. Rees, 10s.; Miss Walker, 1Os.; Mrs. Harry Barker, 5s.; Miss Von Sommer,6s.; Mrs. Thomas Annet, 4s.; Mrs. Barker, 2 turkeys; Hon. THE MOROCCO QUESTION.
FRANCE APPREHENSIVE
SERIOUS MILITARY PRECAUTIONS.
(Gazette's Special Service.) Paris, Saturday Dec. 30. France is taking serious military precautions in view of any unexpected upshot to the Morocco Conference. The Kaiser's specific assu- rances are coupled with his declaration "To me alone does it belong to take a decision,” and this is not considered reassuring.
LIBERAL REFORM OF ARMY. (Gazette's Special Service.) London, Saturday, Dec. 30; Mr. Haldane, the new War Minister, has commenced by cancelling Mr. Arnold-Foster's home-service battalion scheme and has suspend- ed the late War Minister’s Volunteer project.
FAMINE IN JAPAN. (Gazette's Special Service.) London, Saturday, Dec. 30. The famine in Japan is reported to be very serious.
DEATH OF MR. YERKES. (Gazette's Special Service.) London, Saturday, Dec. 30. Mr. Yerkes, the regenerator of urban rail- ways and one of the greatest American finan- ciers, has died at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel in New York. Death was due to complete physical collapse, brought on by overwork. He was a great connoisseur of art and had a superb palace of art treasures. The Press here is strong in its appreciation of his character.
NEW YORK MONEY MARKET, (Gazette's Special Service.) London, Saturday, Dec. 30. Although day-to-day money in New York has gone np to 195 %, this is an entirely arti- ficial price, as stocks rose considerably yester- day.
THE KHEDIVE.
The Khedive attended Friday prayers at the Abou el Ela mosque and returned subse- quently to Abdeen Palace, where he granted some audiences.
While the Khedive was passing by Boulac- street yesterday morning, on his way to the mosque, a native woman made a scene by try- ing to present his Highness with a petition, shouting that she had been unjustly treated. She was quieted by a policeman.
On Thursday, his Highness received General Faradfallah Khan, late Persian Diplomatic Agent at Cairo in audience, and yesterday re- ceived the German Commissioner of the Public Debt, Herr von Mohl, who had the honor to present his elder son, Mr. Hans von Mohl, lieutenant in the Imperial German Navy at Kiel, on Christmas leave at Cairo.
THE GRAND CADI.
The complications in regard to the Grand Cadiship of Egypt appear to be increasing. For some unknown reason the family of the newly-appointed Grand Cadi suddenly left Alexandria for Constantinople on Wednesday, and their unexpected departure has given rise to considerable conjecture in native circles.
It is considered doubtful whether the Cadi will return to Egypt.
NEW CAIRO BOURSE.
We understand that a financial group re- cently put forward a scheme for the construc- tion of a new Bourse at Cairo near the Hammam, on a site belonging to the Société Belge de l’Esbekieh, for which they had acquired an option, which expires on 1st January next. The scheme which was recently put forward met with great opposition on the part of most of the Cairo brokers, the majority of whom signed and approved another scheme to acquire a site for a new Bourse on land belonging to the Société Immobilière d’Egypte.
We understand that there is no probability of any settlement being arrived at between the majority of the brokers and the supporters of the first proposal for some little time.
ASILE RUDOLPH
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.
Dear Sir,— Will you kindly permit me, through the medium of your columns, to thank the generous donors of funds and gifts in kind, who, during the year now closing, have so liberally contributed to the carrying on of the work of the Home, and have by their kind help enabled me to do far more for the poor than I could have been accomplished without their assistance.
Also to thank you, Mr. Editor, for allowing me to make use of your columns to publicly acknowledge the gifts.—I am, etc., P. Rudolph. Alexandria, Dec. 30,
LA DOGARESSA.
M. SINADINO'S FIRST OPERA.
YESTERDAY’S DRESS REHEARSAL
It was yesterday our privilege to attend the dress rehearsal of La Dogaressa, a 3-act opera composed by M. N. Sinadino, with the book by M. V. Sinano, both such promi- nent members of Alexandrian society as to need no farther introduction on our part. This being as we understand, the composer’s first opera, it was scarcely to be expected that the result would be epoch-making and, while the work shows no mean talent for compilation, there is certainly a falling away on the side of creative genius. We have here a produc- tion replete with all the " outward and visible signs ” of grand opera, its church scene with the inevitable bells, its triumphal march, its interspersion of ballet, and its tragic finale; but all these ingredients are such as require to be scored with sweeping power and vivid contrast, and we venture to think that M. Sinadino does not altogether meet these require- ments. He has given us a wealth of dainty music, full of delicate nuances and pleasing romances, but it is clear that he has yet to learn how to make full use of his orchestra and how, in the heavier movements, to stimu- late the senses and impart his message in crisp and penetrating outbursts. He leads up very well to the more involved passages but has evident difficulty in sustaining the " ensemble. " This feature is especially no- ticeable in the first act, which to some degree may be said to want life and firmness of pur- pose ; it elicits some fair opportunities, inclu- ding a quartet of marked merit, and introduces the meeting and subsequent mutual passion of tho Dogaressa (Signa. Bellincioni) and Stellio, the Pisan Ambassador to Venice (Sig. J. Palet).
M. Sinadino is strongly imbued with a Wagnerian tendency, and this influence is displayed particularly throughout Act II, which, while being unquestionably the best act of the opera, is far too redolent of Tann- hauser and Lohengrin to be set down as purely intuitive; the distant trumpets and the heralding of the Doge’s approach follow too closely the huntsmen’s horns (Act I, Sc. 2) and the clarions (Act III) in Tannhauser. Then the chorus of Venetians denouncing Stellio is very much on the lines of the climax of Act III of the same opera, even to the positions taken up by the performers. All this, however, in no way detracts from the many exceedingly good effects which M. Sinadino obtains in this second act. The curtain rises to a graceful minuet air, but with the appearance of the Dogaressa, who has a pretty solo, the music becomes more complex, with an undercurrent of strong motif. The entry of the Doge (Sig. Nicolay) is scored with much grandeur and expression and requires only to be original to be a true masterpiece. The scene, however, is much too protracted; the populace start to welcome their chiefs when he must be an unconscionable distance off. There follows then a sort of allegorical ballet, danced to a valse movement and savouring somewhat of Drury Lane. The act proceeds with the discovery of Stellio’s indiscretions and his consequent disgrace, and terminates with the flight of the Dogaressa after her lover.
To Act III, there is a very beautiful over- ture, exquisitely rendered under Sig. Zuccani’s bâton. It is well orchestrated and proved one of the finest portions of the opera. The scene is now laid on the terrace of a Pallazzo by night and we find the Dogaressa awaiting Stellio, who arrives, rather tardily, and his retreat having eventually been discovered, he is stabbed by order of the Doge's men. To build a whole act on such meagre foundations must, not un- naturally, have taxed M. Sinadino to the utter- most and, although he makes good use of a very Wagnerian motif on the string instruments, there are several drags, which not all Signa. Bellineloni’s efforts, with the valuable aid of Sig. Palet, could eliminate. True, each of them have pleasing arias and the love duet rises to a high pitch of efficiency ; but on the whole (and this applies throughout the opera) the situations are too thin and few to justify the length of the action, and either big cuts or an elaboration of the plot are needed before the intrinsic value of the work is to be gauged. Signa Bellincioni, Sigri. Pallet and Nibolay, no less than Maestro Zuccani, spared no pains to give full effect to their several tasks, while Signa. Zeppilli and Sig. Pasquale were well cast for the respective roles of Bellarmo and Bianca, the confidante. The chorus have not ( very lengthy work but what there was of it was hard and proved rather too much for them. We have no fault to find with the ballet, whose dancing was as graceful as their appearance. The mise-en-scene was very good, though rather too ambitious for the interior of St. Mark's (Act I) and the full expanse of the Piazzetta (Act II) looks palpably unreal when set in miniature on the Zizinia stage.
There was a large number of guests at the rehearsal, and to judge by the warm approval they expressed, we may safely forecast a big success for to-night’s premiere.
NOTICE TO OUR READERS.
Monday next being New Year’s Day, the Egyptian Gazette will not be published on that day.
BERLITZ SCHOOLS OF LANGUAGES,
NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
HOW 'XMAS WAS SPENT.
GREAT CHANGE IN CLIMATE.
(From our Correspondent). Port Said, Thursday. Asked his opinion of Port Said, Mark Twain once remarked, "It is a good town—to be out of !" This appears to have been the opinion of many of the English residents during the celebration of ’Xmas. For those who did not leave the town for the gaieties of Cairo, there were the usual dinners, smoking concerts, dances, 'Xmas trees, and children’s parties.
Services were held on 'Xmas morning at the various churches in the town. In the afternoon, the patients of the Lady Strangford Hospital were entertained by a conjuring performance and variety concert, at which many of the English residents were present.
The football match, Mr. Chessman’s Eleven v. Maltese, ended in a draw, no goals being scored on either side.
Following the spell of wet weather last week we have experienced what might be almost termed an English 'Xmas. Suez has had an even more unique experience in having snow on Mount Attaka. Old European residents in the Canal say that there has been a great change in the climate during the last twenty or thirty years. Passengers coming from India and China have been very much struck with the change in the temperature, and not a few have remarked that it is a foretaste of what they will find in England.
PLENTY OF WARSHIPS.
We have been quite inundated with war- ships of late. H.M.S. Diana arrived here last week, evidently with the intention of re- maining for some time. On Tuesday morning, H.M.S. Euryalus arrived from Australia, where she has been stationed for the last two years. Admiral Sir Arthur D. Fanahawe, late Com- mander of the Australian Squadron, disem- barked at Suez for Cairo, and re-embarked today for Portsmouth.
RUSSIAN CRUISER.
The Russian cruiser Cesarevitch, part of the crew of which mutinied in the Indian Ocean, arrived here to-day. The Russian transport Livonia, with part of the crew of the protected cruiser Oleg, left on Tuesday evening for Lihau.
The French cruiser which took out to Indo- China the submarines Esturgeon and Perle, also arrived to-day.
The Dutch cruiser Koenigen Wilhelmina arrived from Algiers en route for the Dutch East Indies.
REINFORCEMENTS FOR YEMEN. The Turkish transport Adana left for Hodeidah with re-inforcements for Marshal Faizi Pasha in his operations against the rebels in the Yemen.
NEW P. & 0. LINER The new P. & 0. liner Delhi arrived at Port Said on Tuesday evening, under the com- mand of Capt. J.D. Andrews. Her engines have 8,000 h.p. with a speed of 18 knots. Among the passengers was Lord Hawke, the famous English cricketer.
DOCTOR REWARDED. Dr. Pressat, the well-known medical officer of the Suez Canal Co., who carried out exten- sive sanitary measures against malaria at Ismailia, has received one of tho special prizes awarded by the French Academy of Sciences for his original work, "La paludisme et les moustiques."
LUXOR
(From our Correspondent.) Luxor, Thursday.
Never before at this time of the year has Luxor been so fall of visitors.
On Sunday, 24th inst., the English Church was well attended, and a most interesting sermon was preached by the Rev. Professor Sayce on 1 Cor. XIII. 9. "We know in part." There were forty communicants on Christmas Day at the two celebrations, and the preacher was the Rev. A. W. Gross, chaplain, and the offertory for the Luxor Hospital for Natives amounted to 11.13.10. Bishop Potter, of New York, celebrated on Dec. 27 (St. John’s Day). Over one hundred visitors sat down to the excellent fare provided at the Luxor Hotel on Christmas Day, and the "small dance" in the evening was well attended, and very enjoyable.
The Sporting Club held its first Gymkhana of the season (in aid of the local charities) to-day, and 80 Europeans paid for admis- sion, while the natives from the town and neighbourhood came, as usual, in great force. The racing was excellent, and the committee are to be congratulated on the arrangements made for the amusement of guests and the benefit of several worthy objects. The local police, , under the superintendence of the mrowan, preserved the usual good order on the course and its approaches.
The following was the programme:- 1 Bishareen Arab Race (Sack) 2 Native Water-Carriers’ Race 8 Ladies’ and Gentlemen’s Race. 4 Donkey Boys’ Race 5 Ladies’ and Gentlemen’s Goolah Pegging Race, 6 Buffalo Race 7 Horse Race Natives 6 Camel Race
Messrs. Western and Edleman were starters and the judges were Rev. A. W. Gross, Dr. Snowden, and Mr. Saville. Dr. Saunders was clerk of the course.
THE SUCRERIES.
AFFAIR BEFORE TRIBUNAL.
PROPOSAL REGARDING CREDITORS.
The Sucreries case came up before the Chambre des Faillites of the Cairo Mixed Tri- bunal today. The Court was composed as follows; president, Judge Tuck; assessors, Judge Coghlan, Wierdels, Youssef Bey Aziz, and Moh. Bey Rassim. M. Musséri was European assessor and the Government was represented by Bairam Bey.
Maitre Carton de Wiart informed the Tri- bunal that the following proposal had been accepted by the shareholders of the Sucreries:—
"All Creditors, except mortgaged and pri- vileged creditors, are to get 80 per cent. of their claims, payable in debentures, bearing 5 per cent interest from January. 1, 1910, and redeemable in 60 years at 25 per cent. premium. Up to January 1, 1910, the debenture holders are to receive a minimum of 2 per cent interest, guaranteed by sums deposited at the Banque de France.”
Some discussion followed, the Court remark- ing that these proposals had not been formally put before it, and that the question of the railway, etc, had not bean touched.
Maitre Carton de Wiart applied for a special meeting of creditors to deal with these points, and after further discussion the hearing was postponed for a week.
REDUCTION IN POSTAL RATES.
The following reductions in postal rates will come into force on January 1, 1906:
1. The inland registration fee on corres- pondence for Egypt and the Sudan will be reduced from 10 ms. to 6 ms.
2. The commission on inland money orders will be reduced from 4 ms. to 3 ms. for every LE. 1 or fraction thereof, the minimum commission being 10 milliemes.
PAN-EGYPTIAN GAMES. Pan-Egyptian Games are to be held at Cairo on the 9th, 10th, and 11th February next, under the auspices of the Hellenic Athletic Association "Iphitos" of Cairo, and under the patronage of the Hellenic Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General at Cairo. The games will be for amateurs only, and invitations to participate have been addressed to all the athle0 tic and sporting clubs in Egypt. The programme of events is long and varied.
GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL.
This hotel gave its first small dance of the season on Thursday night, and despite all the disadvantages of cold and distance, many people braved the elements in order to be present. The Ghezireh Palace has a great re- putation for its dances and entertainments. Indeed, no better background oould be found for pretty frocks and uniforms than its gor- geous halls and salons. Many dinner parties had been arranged for Thursday, and covers for over a hundred and twenty people had been laid. Mr. Curphy was host to fourteen guesrs, including the Hon. F. Morgan, the Hon. and Mrs. C. James, Mr. and Mrs. Heller, Mrs. Bailey, Mr. and Mrs. Rom, Miss Begg, ’ and Mr. Spooner. Col. Gordon was entertain- ing Lieut. Col. Watson and Mr. Carter Wilson among others, and at Sir Hugh Smiley’s table were Capt. and Mrs. Rome and Crook- shank Pasha. Lady Sampson had a party of eight, among whom were Major Davidson and other officers of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers. Capt. Grant had a party of seven. Major and Mrs. Winn were entertaining friends, as also were Major Burnie, Mr. Horrold, Major Hessia, Mr. von Mohl, Mr. Bennett, Mr. Bink- ley, Capt. Wynham, and Mr. and Mlle Saber- casseaux. Many other guests arrived after dinner, and by ten o’clock dancing was in full swing to the strains of most seductive music.
Mrs. Rom was looking her best in white net, the skirt having a deep flounce of white satin, and a trimming in which silver tinsel played an important part. The foil net bodice terminated in a folded corselet and sash of white satin. Miss Begg, who always has the best of times, was wearing very pale pink with lace insertions run through with pink ribbon. Mrs. Rome, whose wedding made such a sensation in the autumn, was in an artistic frock of soft blue, with a touch of the same colour in her hair. Mrs. Bailey was in pink, with an old-world tucker in the corsage, and Mrs. Heller was wearing a most becoming empire gown of black chiffon with appliquées of shad- ed pink roses on this skirt, and pink ribbons threaded in the lace decollatage. Mrs. Winn was in white, with many rufflings of ribbon and much fine lace, and had a pink rose tucked in her hair. Mrs. C. James was in turquoise blue silk with a sash of shaded chené ribbon, with a twist of blue threaded through her coiffure. Mrs, Maclean was in black, but made over white. Mrs. Allan Joseph brought Miss Joseph and her two girl friends, the latter both in white, while Miss Joseph was in pink crêpe-de- chine. Supper was served at about midnight, when over eighty refreshed themselves before dancing out the remainder of the programme.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Moss liner Rameses sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool via Malta, with pas- sengers, mails, and general cargo, including 4,606 bales cotton.
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
Prince Charles, Duke of Sudermania, the second son of the Crown Prince of Sweden, is arriving in Egypt on board a Swedish man- of-war, which is due at Alexandria on the 5th January. On his arrival the Prince will proceed to Cairo.
Prince Christian of Hesse, Captain Mayer, and several of the officers of the German corvette Charlotte were entertained to dinner and a Christmas Tree fête at the German Consulate, Alexandria, yesterday evening by Herr Hellwig, the acting German Consul.
Lord de Clifford and party have reserved rooms at the Savoy.
The Right Rev. C. Potter, Bishop of New York, and party will be back at the Savoy about the 15th January from Upper Egypt.
Mr. and Lady Victoria Machell came up from Port Said by the 12.45 am. train to Cairo on Thursday and were met by a number of friends and colleagues of the Ad- viser of the Ministry of the Interior at the Bab el-Gedid station, where they arrived at 5 p.m. to meet with a warm welcome.
Among other visitors staying at Ghe- sireh Palace Hotel are Viscount and Vicount- ess de Sinety, Admiral Sir Arthur Fan- shawe, K.C.B., Colonel and Mrs Collingwood, Mme I. de Brandys and family, Mr. and Mrs. Pauling and party, Mr. and Mrs. Sparrow, Mr. C. H. Luckham, R.N., Mr. and Mme Sis- bercaseaux, M. de Borros, Mr. and Mrs. J. H. Brockbank, Mr. and Mrs. Neville, Mr. Hamp- son, Miss Leigh and Miss Berry, Miss Gee, Mr. R. R. Beard.
Judge Heggen, of Mansourah, has arrived at Mema House for a change of air.
Capt. H. B.Montagu and Capt. T. C. Wood, of H.M.S. Diana, lying at Port Said, are spending a few days at Mena House.
Col. Augustus Hill and Miss Hill, who have been regular visitors to Mena House for many years, and the Hon. Gerald Otho Fitzgerald, accompanied by General Sir G. Fitzgerald, will arrive shortly to spend the winter there.
This week’s arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, include: Mr. C. P. Beebe; Mr. Franklin Beeba, Boston; Mr. and Mrs. Muggeridge, London; Mr. and Mrs. G. F. London and party, Glasgow; Mr. and Mrs. W. G. Van Horne, Alexandria; Mr. F. A. Belleville, London; Mr. Alexander Leith, London; The Misses P. and D. Rogers, London; Major Hawker Bey, Suakin ; Lady Oppenheimer, Frankfort; Mrs. Spencer Ledyard, London; Mrs. Brigstoke, Isle of Wight; Madame N. Gulbenkian, London; Mr. Essayan, London; Mrs. York and Misses York, London; Capt. and Mrs. C.K. Morgan, Cairo; Mr. and Mrs. E. W. Roperts.
Lady Wraxall begs to thank all those who so generously subscribed for her children’s relief at Christmas, also Mrs. Robinson, for- merly of the Scottish Mission, and Mr. W. T. Whitfield, who raised the subscription on her behalf.
Emin Bey, Turkish Consul General in London, is staying in Cairo.
M. Michel Sinadino has contributed £1 to the funds of the Rudolph Home as a dis- pensation from paying New Year's visits.
Mr. and Mrs. Lang-Anderson and family are going to Cairo to-day to pass the New Year holidays at Shepheard’s.
The following passengers left by the Anglo- American Company’s S. S. Mayflower for the Nile trip yesterday:- Mr. and Mrs. M. J. Lawrence, Herr Consul and Fran Martens, Mr. and Mrs. Proppe, Mr. and Mme Roussella, Mr. and Mrs. A. L. Mumm, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Pennington, Mrs. John A. Wells, Mr. Jean- naire, Mrs. Zachariai.

TO-DAY’S TELEGRAMS.
RUSSIAN REVOLUTION
REVOLUTIONISTS ARRESTED
ARMISTICE ANNOUNCED
Moscow, December 29
The whole of the revolutionary committee was arrested yesterday, and a quantity of bombs and explosives seized. The attack on the police barracks was repulsed with great loss. The revolutionists afterwards distributed pamphlets announcing an armistice. The workmen’s council met in the evening to consider the abandonment of the strike. (R.)
Moscow, December 29
The members of the revolutionary committee have been arrested in consequence of the assas- sination of the chief of the secret police. There is not so much firing now. (Havas.)
St. Petersburg, December 29
Hopes are still entertained for the early pacification of Moscow. (Havas)
NEW P. AND O. STEAMER LAUNCHED.
A new steamer, the Devanha, has just been successfully launched from the yard of Messrs. Caird and Co., Greenock. She is one of four new twin screw vessels, each of 8,000 tons gross, built for the P. and O. Company’s Bombay China mail and passenger services. Having regard to the fact that these ships almost continually employed in tropical waters the cabins, both first and second class, are placed all upon the upper or hurricane deck and are unusually spacious and well ventilated, all being what are known as “outside" cabins. The Delta, the first of these vessels, recently arrived at Bombay, and, although very rough weather was experienced on the voyage, she was found to be exceptionally steady.
Expedition to Esneh
The Institute of Archaeology of the Uni- versity of Liverpool has dispatched an ex- pedition to make explorations and excava- tions in the vicinity of Esneh. The funds have been privately subscribed by Liver- pool citizens. The excavations will be under the charge of the University Reader in Egyp- tology (Mr. J. Garstang), assisted by Mr. E. Harold Jones. A third member of the staff of the same Institute, Mr. Percy B. Newberry, is already at work in Egypt upon the history of the ancient civilisation of this country, under the endowment of Sir John Brunner.
EGYPTIAN ANTHROPOMETRY
In the latest volume of the journal of the Anthropological Institute (vol. xxxv, part i) M. C. S. Myers continues his contributions to Egyptian anthropometry by an investigation the compantive anthropometry of the ancient and modern inhabitants, in which he arrives at a different conclusion from that announced by Miss C. D. Fawcett in Biometrika for 1902. He considers that there is no evidence that the prehistoric and modern population of Southern Upper Egypt differ in physical mea- surement, and that the homogeneity of the prehistoric, as determinable by standard de- viation, is the same as that of the modern population inhabiting like regions of the Nile valley. He finds that the relative correlation of cranial measurements in the prehistoric and modern papulation shows great irregularity and that much caution is needed in basing general conclusions as to the relative closeness of correlation on a few coefficients only.
MARSEILLES GRAND HOTEL DU LOUVRE & PAIX
CALLARD & BOWSER'S BUTTER-SCOTCH
REVUE COMMERCIAL
Coton
Les changements dans la cote d'Amérique indiqués par la clôture de vendredi dernier ayant été insignifiants, la séance écourtée de la matinée de samedi, qui a été presque jour férié, n’a eu aucune importance et après les rares transactions traitées, on a affiché des cours absolument égaux à ceux de la veille.
Le repos a duré juequ’à mercredi. Cé jour là quoique l^Amérique ne nous ait apporté que deux points de baisse, l’ouverture a été calme et la finale faible et en baisse de près de 1/8 de tallari en moyenne sur toutes les échéances de la vieille receite. Mais la véritable surprise pour notre marché a été celle que nous ont servi New York et New Orleans venues respec- tivement avec 22 et 35 points de baisse et qui nous ont fait reculer jusqu’a près de 15 1/8 pour le janvier. Toutefois, dans la soirée, la tenue a été quelqae peu meilleure et à la clôture on a remarqué que chacun partait avec un peu plus d'espoir pour la lendémain, espoir basé sur le pressentiment ou plutôt l'intérêt, mais qui s'est, heureusement pour les haussiers, quand même réalisé. Eu effet, la reprise d'une quinzaine annoncée ce matin par les marchés américains et qui a été un fait aussi inattendu que la baisse d’hier, a été nn véritable beaume pour notre corbeille et ce revirement de New Orléans a fait profiter nos prix d'une amélioration de 1/8 de tallari.
En résumé, la semaine a fini sur la cote de 15 11/32 pour le Janvier et de 15 23/32 pour le Mars, ce qui représente en définitive, sur la clôture dp vendredi passé, une perte de 1/4 pour le premier mois et de 3/16 pour le dernier, tandis que dans le même laps de temps l'Amé- rique a reculé, d’après les cotes qui nous sont connues ce soir, de 17 points environ.
Le Novembre, par contre, s’estenn peu mieux comporté, car la perte pour cette échéance n'est que de 5/32 et ce fait est dû à l'élargissement du report sur les mois rapprochés et au désir que montre la spéculation de se jeter sur les dates éloignées, ce qui est toujours un signe de la faiblesse du détenteur des contrats.
Quoique réduite à presque trois journées de travail en tout, la semaine que nous passons en revue n’en a pas moins été intéressante sous le rapport des fluctuations; il n’en est cependant pas moins vrai aussi que, comme activité, le marché a laissé et laisse encore beaucoup à dé- sirer : les continuels changements subits et rarement justifiés désorientent la spéculation de notre place et ont fini par la fatiguer et c'est tout aussi bien à cette circonstance qu'au man- que de contre-partie sérieuse, quand les haus- siers veulent réalises, qu’il faut attribuer l’hésitation qui se fait remarquer et qui rend ou fait parsitre notre marché comine icchabile à réagir par lui-même. II est certain que cette situation ne s'éternisera point, mais pour le moment, cela est incontestable, la tendance n'est guère favorable.
Le mouvement de baisse qui avait commencé en Amérique et qui s'est arrêté, va probable- ment reprendre; dans tous les cas, il ne constitue pas un fait nouveau, car il y a long- temps déjà qu’on le prédisait ou prévoyait. Et quant aux causes qui l'ont engendré, elles consistent, au dire des dépêches qui depuis quelques jours nous viennent de New York et de Liverpool, en plusieurs faits qui ont leur importance et qui méritent d'être retenus, soit, notamment, arrivages dépassant toute attente, pronostics comme recettes pour les deux prochains mois supérieurs à toute idée qu’on s’en faisait, situation politique inquié- tante et desir intense du Sud de yendre. On a parlé en outre de la liquidation des positions des Outsiders de Wall Street, largement inté- ressés dans les cotons et que le resserrement d’argent sur la place de New-York oblige aujourd’hui à se débarrasser de leur marchan- dise, ainsi que de la réserve de Manchester qui, quoique engagé pour de longs mois encore et quoique soutenu, ne trouve pas moyen d'entamer de nouvelles affaires importantes.- On ne peut certes discuter ce qui est avancé sur la question de la récolte et qui peut être tout aussi vrai qu’entâché d'exagération, mais les deux derniers points sont à examiner: La position de Wall Street constitue au fond le point de départ, car c’est elle que l'on visait et rien ne nous dit que le jour où, par suite de la baisse, elle aura entière- ment disparu, nous ne verrons pas les chefs des clans baissiers actuels tourner casaque dans l’espoir de réussir un mouvement dans le sens opposé ; quant à l'abstention de la filature, ne serait-il pas logique de penser que ce qui lui fait défaut aujourd'hui, c'est-à-dire les nouvelles commandes, affluera chez elle quand la véritable consommation croira que la baisse a dit son dernier mot? Les situa- tions, tout naturallement, changent suivant les circonstances et surtout suivant les prix!
Maintenant, comme résumé de l’opinion qui prévaut même parmi quelques-uns de ceux qui ont été les plus assidus à prêcher la baisse, on dit que si les cours sont inévitablement desti- nés a tomber encore, celane signifie pas que l'on doive désespérer de l'avenir, mais que ceux qui seront entrés dans l’article à un niveau modéré, comparativement aux prix que nous avons eus eu dernier lieu, auront pour eux toutes les chances de réus ite : la consommation actuelle est forte et, à tout prendre, elle continuera a l'être, can pou plus tard, il y aura sur le tapis la question de la laine, chère et n'offrant pas un approvisionnement sufficant, sinsi que le déficit, désormais constaté, des récoltes du Lin et de la Jute qui nécèssiteront des remplace- ments partiels en cotons.
Le marche du disponsible est lolu d’avoir été brillant : il a non seulement souffert de l’inter- ruption des affaires es contrats, mais la de- mande en ellée-même du duhors et de la part de nos exportateurs a été leute et peut-être plus lente que ce n’est généralement le cas à l’épo- que des fêtes de fin d’année. Et pour ce qui est des prix qui avalent fléchi en sympathie avec les futurs, ils se sont relevés aujourd'hui et finissent à la même cote que vendredi dernier.
Les exportations de la semsine ont constitué une petite: désillusion pour les intéressés à la hausse avec leur total de Balles 16,000 contre Balles 22,000 pour la même huitaine en 1904. On s’attendait à mieux, mais l’on espère main- tenant une compensation pour la semaine prochaine, qui est la première du mois, d’au- tant plus que pour l’année passée pour la même période il n’y a eu que 16,000 Balles.
Le mouvement de b récolte, eu égard à son importance, continue dans des conditions nor- males, l'avance dans les recettes étant de Can- tars. 180,000 et dans les exportations de 150,000 Cantars. Quént au stock, il n’est que de 31,000 Cantars en moins. Comme retraits, le surplus des expéditions à cette date se partage en parts égales entre l’Amérique et l’Angleterre.
Réduite à la portion congrue, la semaine n’a pas pu être trop favorable à Liverpool pour nos cotons ; aussi tout ce que l'on peut dire est que les ventes ont été insignifiantes, que le disponible est resté invariable et que les futurs se présentent en définitive avec cinq points de baisse.
L'Américain n’a pas été mieux traité sous le rapport de l'aotivité, et pour ce qui est des prix les variations sont égales à peu près aux diflé- rences enregistrées en Amérique soit en tout 10 à 12 points de baisse.
Graines de Coton
La semaine a été favorable au disponible tant par suite de la demands, que de la meilleure tenue des contrats. Le fait est que les cours en ont profité et que ce matin ils ont fini à 58 1/2.
Les exportations sont restées inférieures aux prévisions et cela à cause des iêtos et de quelques retards de la part de certains bateaux à charger, mais ce qui est différé n’est pas perdu.
L’Angleterre semble toujours bien disposée pour nos graines et n’edt pas du tout récal- citrente à répondre à tout raffrrmissement de notre marché. Hull paierait aujourd'hui 5 16/3.

HELOUAN RACES.
FIRST WINTER MEETING.
Fine, clear weather and a warmer sun than had been felt for weeks past marked the first Winter Meeting of the H. S. C., and it was not surprising that the races were capitally attended, while the sport itself was very fair, though there were no peculiarly exciting finishes, and the Pari Mutuel did not pay wonderfully well for places, though the backers of Lakik (ex Rais) for a win in the third race were well rewarded. Among those present we noticed H. H. Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, Lieut. - Gen. Lance, C.B., Capt. Gillson, Mr. Verschoyle, Mr. and Mrs. Soott-Dalgleish, Mr. and Mrs. Stout, Mr. Moberly, Capt. and Mrs. Claude Rome, Mr. Rafferty, Major and Mrs. Spong, Mrs. Wynn, Mr. and Mrs. Somers, Capt. and Mrs. Wilson, Mrs. and Miss Nungovich, Dr. A. J. Bentley, Ishak Bey Hussein, Ibrahim Bey Cherif, Ahmed Bey el Bakri, Omar Bey Sultan, Moharrem Pasha Chehin, and many others.
The railway communications worked very well this time, contrary to certain experiences of last year, and but for a trifling delay on the return journey there was nothing what- ever to criticise in the railway arrangements. The Band of the 1st K. R. Rifles played selections during ths afternoon which were much appreciated. The following are particu- lars of the racing :

FASHION NOTES.
The weather was uncommonly kind to all those who journeyed out to the Helouan race meeting yesterday, and a brilliant sun shone brightly all the afternoon, much to everybody’s satisfaction. A good number of Cairo people were present, and nearly all the ladies were in cloth tailor-made suits, though a certain num- ber took advantage of the sunshine and donned more summery attire. Captain and Mrs. Wilson were there receiving the congratulations of their many friends, Mrs. Wilson wearing a pretty pale blue frock and black hat with many roses tucked under the back of the brim. Mrs. Claude Lome looked well in a smart black and white check suit, the belted coat having a short barque and pale blue embroidered revers, and round her shoulders a beautiful sable boa. Sable was also worn by Mrs. Somers over a perfectly fitting frock of palest grey cloth. Her toque was of the same fur. Mrs. Winn, who is always a striking figure, was gowned in white cloth with a sable stole. Her small toque of vivid green with one white camilla was draped with an enormous flowing veil of green. Mrs. Stout was in a very neat coat and skirt of grey cloth with cuffs and revers of black velvet, and Mrs. Spong was in white with much brown tulle in her hat. Mrs. Nungovich was wearing black doth inlet with pale blue, which blue toned in with the superb engraved turquoise on her chain and in her hat of ermine. Miss Nungo- vich was much admired in her soft grey suit with a large white fox around her shoulders. Mrs. Herrling, who was with her, was in white with a pale blue chiffon hat.

A MOTHER AND HER CHILDREN.
11, Kitchener Terrace, Tynemouth Road. North Shields, England.
For the sake of other mothers, I must tell you how your Doan’s Backache Kidney Pills have helped me.
I have never been strong, and can trace my kidney trouble back to the days of my childhood: Even when a girl in my teens, I was.tired and drowsy all the day, and didn't get restful sleep at nights. As I grow in years, I seemed to get worse, being irregular, and having attacks of palpitation and nervousness. Between 16 and 17 years of age I couldn’t go up half a dozen stops without resting; if I attempted to, I fell down. About this age, too, I began to be troubled with sharp pains in the small of the back, and was sometimes taken with dizzy spells.
Time after time I had medicine from the doctor, but it didn’t seem to help me at all.
After my 21st birthday, I became more regular, and my health improved, although I still suffered now and then from backache, headaches, and dizziness, and the secretions werfe irregular in passing. I married when I was 24 years of age, and have had, in all, six children, the five born before I began with Doan’s Backache Kidney Pills being premature. The first lived only 11 months, the second and third are still living ; the fourth lived only 24 hours, and the fifth died within three weeks.
It was about 12 months ago that I began taking Doan’s Backache Kidney Pills, having heard them spoken highly of. The first box relieved me a good deal, and I bought some more which considerably eased my back and improved my appetite. By keeping on with the medicine, I grew better in every way. Shortly after this, I gave birth to my sixth child ; it is the only child not prematurely born, and is going on splendidly—better, in fact, than the other two who survived. It it just two months old now.
Altogether I have used six boxes of Doan’s Backache Kidney Pills, and they have done me more good than all the doctors’ medicine. I sleep better at nights, my appetite is im- proved, and I am a healthier woman now than I have been for many years.
You are weloome to publish these facts, and I shall be glad if my experience proves helpful to other mothers.
(Signed) (Mrs.) H. MILLER.
Doan’s Backache Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 13 per box or P.T. 71 for 6 boxes; or they may be had direct from the general agent for Egypt,— Max Fischer, Hotel du Nil Street, Mousky, Cairo.

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.
THE ABBASSIEH OASIS
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
Sir,—The remarks of the Financial Adviser on speculation in land are of some interest, but it is strange that there is no allusion in this part of his Note to tbhe Abbassieh Desert affair. Sir Vincent Corbett states with a full sense of the responsibility attaching to his opinion that Egypt is not an El Dorado for investors. If, however, the Egyptian Government, advised by him, is prepared to offer any more land on similar terms to the Ahhassieh deal, there is still an El Dorado in this country, richer than the wildest dreams of a varice. The public still await an explanation of the Abbassieh Desert Oasis affair, and also some information as to the prices already being asked by the happy con- cessionnaires for plots of this land.—I am, etc.,
An Earnest Inquirer.
Cairo, December 28.
THE INCIDENT OF DECEMBER 10.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
Sir,—I have read with much interest, in your columns, the opinions expressed by several correspondents at to the cause, effect, and importance, of the row which occurred in Alexandria on the 10th inst. According to some, it was a premeditated outbreak of some importance whereas others affect to regard it as little more than a Sunday afternoon’s amuse- ment ; others again fancy that it was due to turbulent foreigners, and others say that it was an expression of native discontent.
Your most recent correspondent on the subject, who hails from Port Said, regards it with mixed feelings, for within the limits of the same column be admits that it might be a blessing in disguise, and then goes on to speak of it as the disaster which we have to deplore. This gives evidence of a lack of logic not often to be found in your paper; many of the opinions expressed in this letter are quite irrelevant to the subject, and show so little knowledge of Egypt, that I should recommend your correspondent in future to confine his observations to Port Said.
However much opinions may vary about the incident of the 10th December, the fact still remains, that it was sufficient to justify the authorities in arresting several hundred people, and it has entailed no small amount of work and responsibility on the judges of the Native Tribunals, who appear to have acquit- ted themselves of their difficult task with laudable impartiality.
While it is useless to deny that the incident was of some importance, it is equally pleasing to note, that although all sorts of rumours were current that there would be a renewal of the disturbance, all the European colonists here were able to go about their business or their pleasure much as though nothing had happened. Some of us know from sad experience that such is not the case in a neighbouring country when such incidents occur —why did we have this feeling of security? The answer to this question is clear : it is because the British flag flies on the Kom el-Dik Fort, and the White Ensign in the harbour of Alex- andria, and if the latter is not always there it is not far to seek.—I remain, etc.,
Observer.
Alexandria, 29th December, 1905.

BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Au jour d'hui a midi et demis)
Bien que nous soyons un samedi, la cor- beille des valeurs a présenté une animation exceptionnelle,en prévision sans doute des deux jours de chômage qui vont suivre et de la brièveté de la séance de ce matin qui a olôturé à 11 heares et demie.
L’activité a porté sur toute la ligne, mais principalement sur la National Bank, l'Agricole les Estates, la Salt & Soda et la Nungovich.
La hausse inauguree hier en Obligations Crédit Foncier s'accentue aujourd’hui de 325 à 332. On a même fait à un moment donné 334.
Un engouement semblable a eu lien pour la Banque d'Abyssinie qui a ouvert à 7 1/4 soit en hausse d'une demi-livre sur le prix de clôture d'hier. Vers la fin, cependant, le cours a fléchi à 7 1/16 vendeurs.
La Nungovich gagne toujours du terrain. Elle s'avance de 11 1/2 à 11 9/16, avec de nombreuses transactions.
De 9 5/16 l’Agricole remonte aussi à 9 3/8 et la Cassa dî Sconto de 213 1/2 à 215.
Et les petites valeurs ne sont pas moins favorisées ; l'Investment reprend de 1 5/32 à 1 3/16, la Delta Land de 2 1/16 à 2 1/8 et la New Egyptian de 29/3 à 29/6.
Les Estates, continuant leur mouvement ascensionnel, atteignent le cours de 1 9/16 vendeurs.
Eu revanche, les Markets fléchissent de 26 à 25/9, la Nile Cold Storage de 11/16 à 5,8 et la Banque d'Athènes de 130 à 129 1/2.
Les Sucreries se relèvent peu à peu. On a clôturé à 30 aujourd’hui.
Il y a hausse également en Khedivial Mail de 4 3/8 à 4 7/16. L’Ordinary gagne 3 pence à 26.
On voit par ce cours aperçu que l’ensemble de notre marché est excessivement forme. Une pareille venue es fin d’année fait présager une brillante ouvertore pour l'année qui com- mence.
Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Caire 29 Décembre.
Le taux d’escompte à Londres vient d'être de nouveau élevé à 4% ce qui doit, assuré- ment, être attribué aux besoins considérables d'argent qui se manifestent d'habitude dans les derniers jours de l’année. Le Consolidé anglais est renseigné invarié, de même que toutes les valeurs égyptiennes.
A Paris égalemént, l’action Crédit Foncier est signalée stationnaire à 778. La Banque d'Athènes est en hausse de 2 francs à 126.
Ici, le marché des valeurs a été, ce matin, tort animé et en- excellente tendance. Ces bon- nes dispositions font espérer que, les fêtes pas- sées, janvier donnera plus de satisfaction.
Les transactions out été très nombreuses en National Bank et en Agricole; la première a clôturé en hausse d’un 1/4 de livre à 25 7/16 ; la seconde à 9 5/16. La Cassa di Sconto a gagné 6 francs à 214. L’action Crédit Foncier, en bonne demande, s’est inscrite à 781 ; l’obliga- tion à lots 1886 a haussé de 6 francs à 325.
L'Immobilière a avancé de 330 à 338. Le projet consistant à construirs la nouvelle Bour- se du Caire sur un des terrains de la Société n’est peut être pas stranger à ce mouvement.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich out ouvert à 11 3/8 pour clôturér à 11 1/2 sur de forts achats. Les Upper Egypt ont clôturé à 5 5/32. Les National Hotels se sont maintenus à leur prix précédent.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les New Egyptian sont soutenues à 29.6 acheteurs. Les Estates, très mouvementés, ont clôturé à 1 17/32. Les Salt and Soda ont gagné 1 shelling à 21.3.
Les Sucreries d'Egypte ont, elles mémes, haussé de 5 francs à 30.
Alors qu’on s’attendait à une accentuation de la baisse sur le coton par suite dee nouvelles d’hier, les marchés d’Amérique nous transmet- tent, au contraire, des cours en hausse; le spot a gagné 5 points, le Janvier et le Mai 14 point respectivement. Liverpool est également plus ferme.
Ici, ce matin, le Mars a ouvert à 15 3/4 pour clôturer au même prix.
A l'occasion des fetes da nouvel An, il y aura demain séance de 10 h. à à 11. 30 a.m. Lundi 1er Janvier, la Bourse sera fernée.
MM. H. de Vries Boutigny, agents de change, se chargent de l’exécution de fous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marchés de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, An- vers, Liverpool et New-York La Circulaire quotidienne de la maison est envoyés sur demande.

S. STEIN
OUR LONDON LETTER.
(From our Correspondent).
London, December 21
Quem Jupiter vult perdere—whom Jove would destroy he first deprives of reason. The saying’s worn, but no other meets the case of C.B. With inconceivable candour and self- destructive obstinacy he outlined at the Albert Hall last night such a policy as the British Empire has never been asked to consi- der, save in nightmares. This Liberal programme is simplicity itself. Our arma- ments, the pledges of peace which the strong man armed can provide, the means which made possible the successful foreign policy of Lord Lansdowne (which C.B. finds so "pleasant" an outlook) and the many arbitra- tion treaties concluded by the Unionist Admi- nistration, are to be reduced. Free Trade is to take their place, and war is to be avoided, not by the knowledge that we can defend onr own interests, but by our power to buy off our ene- mies with enlarged opportunities for "dump- ing.” And. this is C.-B.’s answer to Mr. Balfour and Mr.Chamberlain:
After this it need surprise no one to know that Lord Kitchener is directly threatened, that trade onions are to be granted immunity from the legal restrictions placed on the con- duct of ordinary mortals, that economies are to be effected hy the Gilbertian process of removing all checks upon municipal enterprise and extravagance, that farmers are to he benefited by imposing fresh burdens on land so overburdened as to be already unprofitable, that the ratepayer is to be mulcted for a sop to the educational Cerberus, that the publican is to be robbed in the sacred name of intemperate Temperance, and that local control of its own affairs is to lead Ireland by swift steps to that separatist haven which is Home Rule.
With excellent judgment and good taste Lord Curzon has declined the invitation to stand for the City. It was conveyed to him in terms of the highest compliment, and was backed by the signatures of men whose names speak for themselves, as rrpresenting the finance and commerce of London. It was, indeed, a great temptation, but Lord Curzon has, as might have been expected of him, risen superior to it, and has set an example which lesser persons would do well to follow. Rather than that his action should be a source of embarrassment to political parties, or "accen- tuate differences" which it would be his "single aim to unite,” he forgoes a unique opportunity of returning to public life, under conditions so appreciative of his character as a man and a high official.
I am not surprised that Lord Welby, when questioned on Tuesday as to the fall in County Council stocks, replied that "he could not give a satisfactory answer.” While Consols have fallen 1 3/4 percent in the last nine months, London County Council securities have dropped 4 1/4, and the explanation, while very far from "satisfactory," is even to the financial use phyte, sufficiently obvious. It was illustrated in a timely fashion by the proceedings of the Council itself yesterday afternoon. The sums voted at this single sitting included £139,000 for tramways, £110,000 for workman's dwellings, £111,000 for a school training college, and £10,000 and £25,000 for other educational buildings—making, with odds and ends, a total disbursement of £700,000 for one afternoon. And this takes no account, of course, of the weekly £2,500 spent upon the steamboat procession. It is not surprising that the judi- cious investor should look shyly at the scrip of a municipality which is only happy when it is throwing money about.
In an interesting report, just published by the Foreign Office, on the trade of Switzerland, some striking figures are given with regard to the travellers, commercial rather than globe- trotting, who visited the pleasure-garden of Europe during 1904. In the course of last year no fewer than 4,800 representatives of German houses obtained the requisite licences, whereas only 41 travellers from the United Kingdom made application for permits to solicit business in the various cantons. It is a notable fact, however, that although there were more than a hundred German travellers to our one in Switzerland, the totol imports from the Fatherland were only seven times the volume of British trade, which proves that our goods are in demand, despite our sad lack of enterprise.
From the standpoint of the picturesque, it is excellent news that the roof of Chariot Cross Terminus is to be considerably lowered in height. That should render the hideous eyesore somewhat less obtrusive, and it may even be hoped that while reconstruction is in hand, the owners will take advantage of the opportunity to impart some architectural merits to the structure. But aesthetic improve- ment fades into insignificance, important though it be, compared with the revelation of public peril from the growing use of iron and steel, cast or wrought, in buildings. Such a wide variety of antagonists pronouncements from experts is appearing that no definite con- clusion can be drawn from their dogmas.
The announcement that Mr. Beerbohm Tree will shortly take a touring company to Ger- many with a Shakespeare repertoire is one that wilL meet, of course, with an extremely cordial weloome from English residents in the Fatherland. But the significance of the visit goes further than this. It is, in a way, a return visit to that of the German Theatre in London, and an important item in the free interchange which is so valuable a stimulus of the world's art.
It appears that the most terrible consequences of the Boer War have been overlooked. Many reputations were lost during the fighting. They were inconsiderable in comparison with the reputations that have taken flight since. The first were professional, and concerned only the national safely. The others are sartorial, and strike at the roots of the national beauty. In plain—awfully plain—language, the British officer who used to set the fashion in dress— where silk hats and frock coats were as near perfection as mortals could expect—returned from South Africa with a lowered sense of social demands and-his own personal respon- sibility. What South Africa began the develop- ment of the motor-car is completing. The “Outfitter” is almost in tears over the shame- ful carelessness now manifest in the beat circles. A Norfolk jacket and riding breeches, accom- panied by a cap and gaiters, are accepted “even on Sundays.” Carelessness in dress has become "firmly rooted” in the minds of the "gilded youth of this country," and if things go on as they are now going the "smartly groomed man will be as extinct as the dodo.” It is deplorable.
Mr. George Herring’s gift of £100,000 will enable the Salvation Army to work out an experiment in "farm colonies" which should prove of the highest importance. It is of much significance that the money is only a loan as far as the Salvation Army is concerned—being ultimately payable by instalments to the King’s Hospital Fund—for this implies that it is hoped to conduct the undertaking on com- mercial lines, and to replace the capital intact after setting the scheme in operation. If this programme can really be fulfilled, it will mark a great advance in practical sociology.
We must adapt Macaulay's famous conun- drum and inquire to-day whether, as civilisation advances, fecundity declines. According to Drs. Newsholme and Stevenson, who discoursed on the subject of birth-rates to the Statistical Society on Tuesday, the augmentation of the race is slowing down nearly everywhere. Ireland is the only country in which the cradles are being kept more busy than formerly, while the rest of the world is applying the philosophy of "comfort” in a way that has a marked influence upon statistics. It is some consolation to know that, while the English birth-rate is 17 per cent lower than twenty-two years ago, that does not represent an extreme retrogression, for Belgium and Saxony have each got a decrease of 24 per cent. against them.
It is interesting to note that the Ireland and Craven scholar for this year at Oxford is a Rhodes scholar. It is a proof of the soundness of Mr. Cecil Rhodes' scheme, and of the excel- lent material hitherto lying dormant in the outlying parts of the Empire Indeed, efforts are already being made in other Universities to give encouragement to colonials to graduate. That they will hold their own in the athletic world may be deduced from the fact that three of the Oxford fifteen in the Varsity match of this year were from South Africa. Indeed, from the extraordinary success of the New Zea- landers, it is probable that undergraduates will come from the colonies to teach; not to learn, in this respect.
In common with all who are interested in the genuine progress of the motor-car, I rejoice at the decision of the International Association of Automobile Clubs that there shall be no Gordon Bennett race next year. Nor, I understand, in any future year. While the motor car was still merely a new toy for a few rich men, the existence of such a competition was at any rate comprehensible. Its continuance now would be pointless and inexcusable. It is universally realised that the motor-car has a serious future before it, and that its development lies on the lines of reliability rather than of speed. But the fixture is not merely to be dropped ; it is proposed to substitute for it a competition of a practical kind for touring cars. The inter- national element, so valuable for purposes of comparison and improvement, will thus be preserved, but now at last it will directed to its right and proper channel.
There is a locus classicus of a reporter, hav- ing to transcribe his notes on a speech on education at great speed, writing “kids” throughout instead of "children." As is very commonly done, he had used the shorter term through his notes to save time. Exactly the same thing has happened in the last speech of Lord Durham's. He describes his horror at finding himself reported as referring to Mr. Chamberlain throughout as “Joseph" and "Joey.” It was explained that the reporter had written "Joe," and a sub-editor added the “y.” A somewhat similar mistake has sometimes been made in mentioning the names of speak- ers. A reporter, ignorant of the names of those on the platform, often pats down some personal characteristic or feature, and inquires the name afterwards. A reporter recently forgot to make the inquiry, and the speaker figured as "Mr. Clubfoot."
THE NATIVE PRESS.
MOSLEM INSTABILITY.
The following article on some characteristics of present-day Moslems appears in "Al Moayad." The author is Mohamed Effendi Kurdali, the popular and well-known Da- mascene writer and editor of "Al Moktabas," a review which has recently made its appear- ance in Cairo:-
"Our society is in a state of dissolution and a condition of despair prevails among all classes, who give way to a belief in destiny. This lack of any strength of will and this want of confidence in the future are great mis- fortunes for the land. Had our great fore- fathers developed th' same characterisitcs as we have, they would have been as full of fear and as poor of spirit even as we are. But on the other hand they strengthened their charac- ters and enlightened their minds by learning, and trampled on all feelings of despair by their zeal and understanding. When any one of our leading men follows a fearless and upright line of policy he is accosted by his fellows with the question, Are you trying to make your nation live for a hundred years while we have enough to do to keep the race going for an- other ten years ? What a difference is there between this fatalistic point of view and the English outlook on life. The people of that race act to-day so that their deeds may bring forth fruit hundreds of years hence. Had you looked back on your history would you have thought it possible that the men of the Crusades, men of a united Christendom, who conquered Jeru- salem and held the coast of Syria and Egypt, would have been forced to withdraw from these lands? Who would have thought that the Moslems would have been strong enough to force them to go away from those countries, which they had ruled for two hundred years? The future should ever be considered by those who take though of the passing day. Had the Moslems in those bygone days given themselves over to despair and placed their hopes solely on divine succour,they would have lost their position and God alone knows what would have beoome of Syria, Palestine, and Arabia. Saleh-ed-Din el Ayoubi and his statesmen were not acting in accord- ance with the advice of scatter-brained council- lors when they gave up the policy of hope- lessness and by their zeal and foresight wrought those mighty deeds, the fame of which still re-echoes in the East. How can we compare the present with those days of old and still believe that heaven snd earth stand yet where they did aforetime? Now-a-days our motto is 'Everything by starts and nothing long.' The best and only line of policy for us, whether for the farmer in his farm or the great man in his palace, is to develop strength of will and firmness of purpose. Education and culture should be our aims, and indifference and hopelessnees should be ruthlessly uprooted from our sentiments, for to fail after a struggle is better for the develop- ment of character than to gain success without work."
In reading this description of the defects of the Arab character we are reminded of the recently published and remarkable work of Mr. Phillips on the desert, with its subtle analysis of the Arab. The Arab is the eternal individualist, the antithesis of the citizen. He is terrible in his sudden explosions of nervous energy, terrible as the desert, he he cannot endure, and, like the desert, he can destroy but never build. His mind has brilliance and swiftness, bnt neither profun- dity nor coherence. Sometimes in bis paral- lels Mr. Phillips is farfetched and fantastic, but in the main his brilliant analysis carries oonviotion, when he traces throughout the history of Mohamedanism the desert spirit which stops short of all complete achieve- ment and endaring civilisation. It has the force of a destroying angel, but it goes as suddenly as it comes:-
"Orthodox Mohamedanism, reeking as it does of the desert, energetic and militant, yet failing in just the qualities which give depth to thought and coherence to society, is, after all, the best clue to the Arab's character and history. It explains both his successes and his failures. It explains the fury of his attacks, the rapidity of his conquests, and his success in destroying and consuming all that is rotten, effete, and worn out in the world. It explains the lack of definite pur- pose in all his undertakings, and his failure to build up anything durable and solid of his own. It explains why in the twilight of the middle ages he was so prominent and terrible a figure, and why to-day he is back in the desert once more.
This Arab strain in the Egyptian character probably explains the complete failure of all attempts to run native limited liability com- panies.
